Title: I'm only a hand sewer..can I tackle making 'simple' bedroom curtains?
Message:
Parts of the curtain making process are best done by hand, in fact easier, as you are working flat on a table rather than pushing it through a sewing machine. Might be a day or two. But other parts are normally machined and stronger that way.  Joining the vertical lengths and sewing on the pencil pleat tape for example. You could also hand sew these but it would take a while. 
Have you got space to make curtains? Also you will need an iron/ironing board.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0953526755/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_CM801HB82FNTSHH6WND3?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 helpful book]]
Cleaned_Message: curtain making process best done hand fact easier working flat table rather pushing sewing machine might day two normally way joining vertical sewing pencil pleat tape example could also hand sew would take got space make also need iron board ref apa tag helpful book

Title: Dd8 refusing to do anymore school  work from home from tomorrow
Message:
there are most likely four and a half weeks of remote learning left assuming you are in England less in Scotland. It wonâ€™t make the slightest difference to your daughters results in high school, GSCEâ€™s or life chances if she does not do any more official school work. 
Does she like animals ? If so this book is great The Animal Lover's Fun-Schooling Journal: Homeschooling Curriculum Handbook for Students Majoring in Zoology | The Thinking Tree (60 Day Emergency Homeschooling Curriculum Plan) [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/195143501X/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_i_5G48W76D95AJFYHB2E2C?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] if not there are books in other topics. 
Encourage her to watch educational programs play minecraft, draw etc. But even if she doesnâ€™t do anything remotely educational itâ€™s absolutely fine.
Cleaned_Message: likely four half remote learning left assuming less make difference high school life official school work like book great animal lover fun schooling journal curriculum handbook zoology thinking tree day emergency curriculum plan ref tag encourage watch educational play draw even anything remotely educational absolutely fine

Title: Year 7 friendship dramas
Message:
She will meet her own people OP, at the end of the day she has had really only one term effectively at Secondary. There isnâ€™t much she can do in lockdown but if she has good Primary friends outside of this group then I would encourage her to keep in contact with them now, it will provide some balance and help her feelings of self worth.

From what you have said, while she might not feel this friendship group value her, she has doubts about them too. While removing herself completely from social media groups they are in together isnâ€™t the answer, I would encourage her to stop checking messages, statuses etc on a frequent basis and to lessen the frequency of her messaging involvement - remove herself slowly basically. Perhaps limit her mobile usage? DD2 is only allowed it after the end of homeschooling and up to 7pm. Itâ€™ll give her some mental space too.

This is just a first year blip and try not to angst about it yourself. She will find others she likes a lot more and who will like her as much too, she just needs to start trying to find them  - this kind of experience and solving it builds social resilience and in Year 7 they are effectively trying on friends like new clothes. DD2 has this book which she finds helpful (probably more so than talking to me as Iâ€™m too forthright!) - [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Queen-Bees-Wannabes-Boyfriends-Realities/dp/0307454444?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Cleaned_Message: meet people end day really one term effectively secondary much good primary outside group would encourage keep contact provide balance help self worth said might feel friendship group value removing completely social media together answer would encourage stop frequent basis lessen frequency involvement remove slowly basically perhaps limit mobile usage end give mental space first year blip try angst find lot like much needs start trying find kind experience social resilience year effectively trying like new clothes book helpful probably talking forthright queen bees tag

Title: Stop 5 month rubbing her face
Message:
A quick update in case helpful for anyone else. We decided to go for the Snoozzz sleep wrap  suggested. This enabled us to continue to swaddle even though baby had learned to roll over. Was brilliant- we all slept really well.

We tried to transition her out of the swaddle at 7.5 months using the love to dream transition swaddle. We released one arm for a few nights but found she was waving it around all night and disturbing herself. We ended up putting a long-ish sock over her hand/arm and that helped loads(we found this tip on an old MN thread!). So continued with her arm out and progressed to releasing the second arm and used the sock on it too. 

So far so good. Baby is no longer hitting her face or trying to pull the dummy out and is now no longer using the swaddle or wrap. And she is sleeping really well throughout the night.

So I think our baby just needed a little more time in the swaddle, and the sleep wrap enabled us to do this safely. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B002P98G46/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_F568RK7RWHQM1VM8RSXQ?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Cleaned_Message: quick update case helpful anyone else decided sleep wrap continue swaddle even though baby learned roll brilliant slept really well tried transition swaddle love dream transition swaddle one arm nights found waving around night disturbing ended long sock hand arm found tip old thread continued arm second arm used sock far good baby longer face trying pull dummy longer swaddle wrap sleeping really well throughout night think baby little time swaddle sleep wrap safely ref apa tag

Title: Children experiencing rage due to screens and mirrors
Message:
Iâ€™m struggling with a different kind of child anxiety and was recommended this [[https://www.amazon.com/Breaking-Free-Child-Anxiety-Scientifically/dp/0190883529/ref=sr_1_5?dchild=1&crid=13RGL3SCWWCPF&keywords=breaking+free+of+child+anxiety+and+ocd&sprefix=breaking+free%2Caps%2C188&mc_cid=82b406248a&mc_eid=50bb2e8d4e&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609690812&sr=8-5 book]] by a psychologist. The current thinking on child anxiety is that we should avoid ^accommodating^ it (eg trying to remove all the mirrors in the world, which is our very normal parenting instinct) but instead ^support^ the child in developing confidence and coping skills.  
If you google  Eli Lebowitz and SPACE youâ€™ll find more. The research is very new and recent. 

I hope thatâ€™s helpful; it sounds very difficult
Cleaned_Message: struggling different kind child anxiety breaking free child anxiety scientifically ref breaking free child anxiety breaking free tag book psychologist current thinking child anxiety avoid accommodating trying remove world normal instinct instead support child confidence coping space find research new recent hope helpful difficult

Title: Found a book that kind of helped me  (in a weird way)
Message:
Been feeling down on and off for the last few years. It's gotten worse as I've got older. Nothing I could really put my finger on, just I feel like life isn't going to plan and time is slipping away. Throw in some failed relationships and some bereavement and well you get the picture. I was looking on Amazon for some self help books and came across one that piqued my interest. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Nobody-Knows-account-struggles-depression-ebook/dp/B07ZJYFSJ6/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Not sure if anyone's read it, but the description kind of hooked me. It's funny in a way, it offers no suggestion of help or pointers on how to feel happier, but the mere fact that there's someone else out there that feels very similar is in itself a comfort. Can definitely relate to the birthday section.

Anyways, I'm a KDP subscriber so it was free for me. Thought I'd pass it on.

E.

Title: If you've had a teen and it wasn't plain sailing, please come this way. How would you punish this?
Message:
We had a summer of this when youngest DS was 15. Just all of a sudden. Threefold approach by us: 
1. Sensible conversation about why and feelings (when everyone was calm)
2. Kept him so effing busy with boxing, looking for PT job, football team that he was too knackered to go and get into much trouble 
3. Drew up a consequences chart where we looked at different levels of freedoms and privileges and agreed with him what level he â€œdeservedâ€ It was like a ladder and he knew further misdemeanours would result in moving down a rung of the ladder, in other words he knew what the consequences would be. 

I appreciate that no 2, is totally out of the question right now. 

One book that really helped me was [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Get-Out-Life-bestselling-twenty-first-century/dp/1788163826?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

I wish you luck, and want to reassure you that his 14 years so far are a good guide to how heâ€™ll turn out in the end.
Cleaned_Message: summer sudden threefold approach sensible conversation everyone calm kept busy boxing looking job football team get much trouble drew chart different agreed level deserved like ladder knew would result moving rung ladder knew would appreciate totally question right one book really get life twenty first century tag wish luck want reassure far good guide turn end

Title: If you've had a teen and it wasn't plain sailing, please come this way. How would you punish this?
Message:
*How would you know?*
*If his bedroom is on the first floor (no, we don't have a choice) and he can literally open his window and step out, how would you know?*

*I have no spidey senses that wake me at 11.30pm to tell me one of my offspring has escaped out the window.*

We're disordered light sleeps - often up late and early and  people wandering around I tend to hear and check on and send back to bed  - DH has insomnia often wanders around at night or sleeps downstairs.

Layout - roof is at front of house huge risk neigbours many shift workers would see and say something.  Plus security lights that would trigger which would risk altering us as our bedroom is at the front.

House layout - only really one room we wouldn't hear and then getting back in would be issue - we'd hear any doors and getting back up on the roof  to get in vai window would be hard and moving anything to stand on instantly noticable and there isn't really anything to drag to do that.  Plus as we have indoor cats they all love so they tend to not think of leaving windows open and ajar.


 Youngest window doesn't open quietly and she's in the room next door so we'd hear that one not least as cats insist our bedroom door is open to landing at night.

Plus there are four other people in the house - all of who would say something if one was out and they noticed.

But mainly don't think it's occured to any of them yet - when the get up they've gone for their phones kept downstairs at night  and the gaming compter downstairs and invariable get sent back to bed till a decent hour.  At the moment their friends aren't roaming around those hours either.

So while I'm sure it's conforting to belive I'm hopeless naive and my teens must be slipping out - it's really unlikley though if they did choose to start stopping them would be hard.


As your window is downstairs have  you not thought of a cheap window [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/NRS-Healthcare-Magnetic-Window-Alarm/dp/B00A8L1WG2/ref=sr_1_5?dchild=1&keywords=window+opening+alarm&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1610985326&sr=8-5 window alarm ]] so you'd at least stand a chance of being aware?
Cleaned_Message: would know bedroom first floor choice literally open window step would know wake tell one offspring window disordered light often late early people wandering around tend hear check send back bed insomnia often around night downstairs layout roof front house huge risk many shift would see say something plus security would trigger would risk bedroom front house layout really one room hear getting back would issue hear getting back roof get window would hard moving anything stand instantly really anything drag plus indoor love tend think leaving open ajar window open quietly room next door hear one least insist bedroom door open landing night plus four people house would say something one mainly think yet get gone kept downstairs night gaming compter downstairs invariable get sent back bed till decent hour moment roaming around either sure belive hopeless naive teens must slipping really though choose start stopping would hard window downstairs thought cheap window magnetic window alarm ref window opening alarm tag window alarm least stand chance aware

Title: Happy Christmas Bootcampers!
Message:
*Lyrata* all that dairy might not help your urge to snack. Could you try non-dairy snacks instead? I find a couple of boiled eggs with mayo hits the spot. I usually stir a little curry powder or hot chilli sauce into the mayo for a cheat version of devilled eggs.

*ChristMyArse* --not sure I want to know how THAT username came about!-- 150-170g is a portion of Greek yogurt. Try adding some electrolytes to your water as 4 litres will flush out electrolytes. A sprinkle of salt and a squeeze of lemon juice (bottled lemon juice from the fridge is fine) will help replace sodium and potassium. If it's still a problem then try an [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00SP31TCW?ref=ppxpopmobapshare electrolyte powder]]r* or the Zero electrolyte tables if you don't mind artificial sweeteners. Watch out for creamy coffees as in general we shouldn't be drinking our calories. The constant insulin disruption from dairy can stall weight loss or cause cravings in some people so it's worth experimenting. If you're affected then keep dairy to no more than twice a day. Most people don't need to cut it out entirely unless they're very sensitive.

*Taking* cream is really high calorie so it's definitely worth being cautious about it. We've had people on previous Bootcamps swigging it straight from the pot which really isn't a good idea.

*Jolly* I suggest adding in some low carb snacks between meals to keep you full while you re-adapt to low carb. Hard boiled eggs are good (with mayo as previously mentioned) or a little cheese, or keep some leftovers aside for snacking. I also like celery sticks with cream cheese, especially for late-night-in-front-of-the-TV-munchies.
Cleaned_Message: dairy might help urge snack could try non dairy instead find couple boiled spot usually stir little curry powder hot sauce cheat version sure want know came portion try water flush sprinkle salt squeeze lemon juice bottled lemon juice fine help replace sodium potassium still problem try ref electrolyte powder zero electrolyte tables mind artificial watch creamy general drinking constant insulin disruption dairy stall weight loss cause people worth affected keep dairy twice day people need cut entirely unless sensitive taking cream really high calorie definitely worth cautious people previous straight pot really good idea jolly suggest low keep full adapt low hard boiled good previously little cheese keep aside also like celery sticks cream cheese especially late night front

Title: Bralettes for bigger cup sizes: are they rubbish support?
Message:

Title: Talking about death to a 5 year old
Message:
[[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pFfIEqiJMcc This video: Freddie the Leaf]] is one my children enjoyed around that age, as well as [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Lifetimes-Bryan-Mellonie/dp/0553344021?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 this book - Lifetimes: A Beautiful Way to Explain Death to Children Book by Bryan Mellonie and Robert Ingpen]], I think there is a video version on youtube as well. 

There are a lot of resources out there. Personally - as someone who celebrates DÃ­a de Muertos, but doesn't believe in an individualistic afterlife - I try to talk about it in an age-appropriate way as part of life though I'm not sure I'd describe my method as reassuring. I do avoid euphemisms like being 'lost' or anything that associates sleep or leaving with death, but I also don't associate it with illness (I don't want them to think every illness is deadly) or old age (they're already aware that's not true). It's part of life like the seasons, we talk about those that have died and our ancestors (looking through findthegrave was interesting for mine). We talk about how we don't know when we'll die, we may have feelings about how we want what's left of us treated after death or what we think comes next or we may not, and that's okay.
Cleaned_Message: watch video leaf one around age well tag book beautiful way explain death book think video version well lot personally someone believe individualistic afterlife try talk age appropriate way part life though sure describe method reassuring avoid like lost anything sleep leaving death also associate illness want think every illness deadly old age already aware true part life like talk looking interesting mine talk know die may want left death think comes next may
URLs: ['https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pFfIEqiJMcc This video: Freddie the Leaf', 'https://www.amazon.co.uk/Lifetimes-Bryan-Mellonie/dp/0553344021?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 this book - Lifetimes: A Beautiful Way to Explain Death to Children Book by Bryan Mellonie and Robert Ingpen']

Message:

Interesting. It wasn't when I last looked.

Of course people were able to take the tube to the last public execution in Britain in 1868. London Transport ran special "gallows specials". Just in case anyone was feeling rather smugly civilised at the moment.

There's another book by an abolitionist about the Pierrepoints

Title: Confused.com about periods!
Message:
Thanks. I never thought Iâ€™d be on the other side of this with 3 D.C. My early posting history on mumsnet will be all about my infertility and fears about being childless!

I think the b vitamins would be more likely to regulate your cycle to something functional. Folk who use B6 to â€œlengthenâ€ their cycle are usually just improving their within cycle bleeding and regulating things overall, IYSWIM. It can seem that they have a short cycle because of the duration of bleeding.

Ideally you want a cycle that is about one calendar month long, with ovulation between days 10-14, with no spotting until a definite start to your period around day 28.

This is a really helpful book:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/0091887585/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

Youâ€™ll get there. But people telling you just to keep having sex when you have a long cycle are missing the point -the cycle has to be shortened to be ovulatory. Thatâ€™s not to say you might not randomly ovulate here and there, but the â€œjust sexâ€ approach can get really frustrating very quickly if you arenâ€™t doing anything else to improve the cycle and likelihood of ovulating. If someone is only ovulating 1-3x per year, is it really realistic to just keep having sex every couple of days for several years hoping to catch one of these ovulations? That kind of advice can really kill the intimacy in a relationship with sex becoming an endless chore...
Cleaned_Message: thanks never thought side early posting history infertility childless think would likely regulate cycle something functional folk use lengthen cycle usually improving within cycle bleeding overall seem short cycle duration bleeding ideally want cycle one calendar month long ovulation days spotting definite start period around day really helpful book product ref search title tag get people telling keep sex long cycle missing point cycle say might randomly ovulate sex approach get really quickly anything else improve cycle likelihood someone per year really realistic keep sex every couple days several catch one kind advice really kill intimacy relationship sex becoming endless chore

Title: Have you ever paid duty on an imported item?
Message:
You can generally opt to pre-pay everything or just pay the postage costs. It costs more to pay the courier after the event as they are effectively lending you the money and taking the risk of not paying. They also have extra admin. I expect itâ€™s only available from some companies as they would need to have an IT system which was able to calculate it prior to purchase, theyâ€™d need package weight etc pre-programmed. It is available from quite a few US sellers though, presumably they have high international sales. 
You order directly from Amazon.com, Amazon.co.uk donâ€™t have anything to do with the transaction
Cleaned_Message: generally opt pay everything pay postage pay courier event effectively money taking risk paying also extra expect available would need system able calculate prior purchase need package weight available quite though presumably high international order directly anything transaction

Title: Hey! I'm new here!
Message:
Hi! I'm new here! Well I say new, I've been reading posts for years, but only just signed up to actually answer threads etc.
My eldest son is 9, and I think I know a little about being a parent now, soooooo much more to learn! But after chatting to lots of new mums over the few years I've been a mum for, I noticed how much all of us feel as if we have to compete, or that we aren't quite good enough. Or just how we actually have the same experiences and we don't speak about them! ... So, cut a long story short, I wrote a book and FINALLY in November 2020 (last year wasn't ALL bad) I published it! Its all about, well what I've just said, plus some funny extras, so that you REALLY know that we go through the same things! 
The good, the bad, the ugly and the explosive poos!! 
Well, I will leave it here, before I carry on babbling! Hope you're all coping well with everything that's going on right now in this crazy world! 
If you wanna get through it with a bit of a giggle ans a feeling you're not alone! Please check out my book on Amazon "Motherhood... Wingin' it! In my Pj's" by Cara Jade Sandy its currently on offer for Â£5.60 until January 31st, then it goes back up to its original price of Â£7.99! 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B08NF1RC8H/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_i_cYH.FbERSPPP9?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Take care all! ðŸ˜

Title: We took our eye off the ball and now DS is...
Message:
I agree , it is worth considering something like ADHD as a possibility (just a possibility).  But as others have said since I started typing this (!) can we clarify that ADHD is not a learning â€œdisorderâ€, it is a neuro-diversity and can manifest as hyperactivity, impulsiveness or inattentiveness. Though ADHD can lead to academic and behaviour problems itâ€™s not an accurate gauge of ability/intelligence.  It has to do with the way the brain uses dopamine and the behaviour  describes in their excellent post is what psychiatrists sometimes call â€˜edgingâ€™; doing risky impulsive things to try and get that hit of dopamine.  Itâ€™s worth looking at OP, not in attempt to label and categorise but in order to formulate the best approach and better to check things out and be able to cross them off the list. 
I say this as someone who wasnâ€™t diagnosed with ADHD until 52!  Had a diagnosis been possible back when I was a teen it might have meant that my wild and risky behaviour and my inability to focus and apply myself would not just have been put down to being bad, lazy and stupid.  In the end I got a good degree and career but the path there was very bumpy.

I have a 15 yo DS (he doesnâ€™t have ADHD) and he changed from a sunny and studious 11 into a moody and controversial 12 yo and by 13yo on a mission to push every possible boundary and experiment with every vice.  I agree with the previous posters like  who suggest trying to get him to engage with an activity that is managed by people who really understand the chemical shit storm that is being a teen and will interact with him differently from his parents.  This might give him a way of channelling some of the teen stuff and it might also dilute some friendships by meeting others.  If your DS is anything like mine then itâ€™s important that the suggestion to join some scheme, club, interest group does not come from you!  This takes some creativeness on your part, but he probably needs to feel heâ€™s driving it.  Perhaps there is another male he values such as an older teen who could interact with him/suggest a scheme or interest? Iâ€™ve also found that Iâ€™ve had to change the way I respond to my son and act in a fairly controlled and non-emotional way.  So with vaping, instead of becoming hysterical and pleading with him to stop (which is my natural inclination frankly), I said to him that I know he does it and I recognise heâ€™s curious but that the studies of the dangers are only now coming out and the clever people are the ones that quit and donâ€™t allow the companies producing these things to convince them vaping is edgy or cool.  All said on various car journeys in a Socratic way, asking him his opinion, no lectures.  This roundabout way has allowed a channel of communication to stay open by and large and as he approaches 16 these things have lost their appeal on the whole.  I think youâ€™re entering a period of parenting where keeping a watchful eye, holding back and choosing your battles is required whilst trying to distract him with engagement in activities as above with strong role models, and all the while letting him know youâ€™re there and that heâ€™s loved. He will roll his eyes and may tell you he doesnâ€™t feel the same but it all goes in.  Anyway, thatâ€™s more or less how weâ€™ve stumbled through the teen thing. Itâ€™s not easy.  You might find this book relevant [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Get-Out-Life-bestselling-teenagers/dp/1781253315/ref=mp_s_a_1_2?dchild=1&keywords=drive+me+into+town&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607539903&sr=8-2]]
Cleaned_Message: agree worth considering something like possibility possibility said since clarify learning disorder diversity manifest hyperactivity impulsiveness inattentiveness though lead academic behaviour accurate gauge ability intelligence way brain behaviour excellent post sometimes call edging risky impulsive try get hit worth looking attempt label order formulate best approach better check able cross list say someone diagnosis possible back teen might meant wild risky behaviour inability focus apply would put bad lazy stupid end got good degree career path bumpy sunny studious moody controversial mission push every possible boundary experiment every vice agree previous like suggest trying get engage activity people really understand chemical storm teen interact differently might give way channelling teen stuff might also dilute meeting anything like mine important suggestion join scheme club interest group come creativeness part probably needs feel driving perhaps another male older teen could interact suggest scheme interest also found change way respond son act fairly non emotional way instead becoming hysterical pleading stop natural inclination frankly said know curious coming clever people quit allow convince edgy cool said various car way opinion roundabout way channel communication stay open large lost appeal whole think entering period keeping watchful eye holding back choosing whilst trying distract engagement strong role know roll may tell feel goes anyway less teen thing easy might find book relevant get life ref drive town tag

Title: June 2020 Babies-Newborn, snuggles, recovery, milk and night feeds! 2nd thread
Message:
Yes  we had this exact same issue with Grace as we were using the Ollie the owl but she would stir/wake up after 20mins when it went off.
We ended up getting the marpac hushh and itâ€™s been fab and plays all night until we stop it.
I have heard people use an Amazon echo/Alexa to play white noise through the night too.

Marpac Hushh for Baby [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B01D50RYSC/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_UkK0FbYEZFTQ4?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Cleaned_Message: yes exact issue grace owl would stir wake went ended getting night stop people use echo play white noise night baby ref tag

Title: Puppy crying at night help
Message:
This might help. Gundogs seem to react to this toy quite well.  It has a heat pad and a beating heart so can feel like sleeping with their littermates.

If you carry it around for a while so it smells of you that can help too.  Hope you feel better soon

Title: Live streaming lessons should be banned
Message:

Title: The way I speak to my partner: are we doomed?
Message:
I think a relationship is a dynamic so you will be reacting to things your partner does as well as him reacting to you. So you can't change this alone- you both have to do things differently. 
Have a read of John Gottman, there's loads if you Google and also can I recommend this book [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0752837265/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_chX9FbK1AVFHX?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Its really helpful for how to resolve entrenched patterns in a marriage
Cleaned_Message: think relationship dynamic partner well change alone differently read also recommend book ref apa tag really helpful resolve marriage

Title: drying towels/coats
Message:
They use these kind of towels (different brand) at hydrotherapy, its the same foam like material as the cooling towels if you happen to have one.  After washing the dog down, rub and wring out, it gets a tonne of water off the fur then use the toweling coat to keep warm if air drying. 
The towels go like cardboard if leave to dry out fully so go back in container [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Groomers-AQ002-Aquasorb-Towel-Large/dp/B01FD5Z5OM?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

They use air blaster at hydro which are great if got a thick double coat/long haired dog to blow dry regularly but the cheaper ones Â£50-100 can be noisy.
Cleaned_Message: use kind different brand hydrotherapy foam like material cooling happen one washing dog rub wring water fur use toweling coat keep warm air drying like cardboard leave dry fully back container towel large tag use air blaster hydro great got thick double coat long haired dog blow dry regularly noisy

Title: To think midwife is fobbing me off? *TW* mention of rape.
Message:
You have the right to have the birth you want, and in your circumstances a c section is a perfectly reasonable request.

If you can, please get a copy of The Positive Birth Book ASAP and read it. It is very empowering and gives you the right language to get what you want from your birth.

Agree that you probably need to ask for a different midwife, or for a referral to the obstetrician so that you can talk about it properly.

If you do decide you want to try vaginal birth, all of the internal checks are voluntary and you can decline them. You can chose to do your own cervical examinations. The only time someone *has* to be up your vag is if you need stitches afterwards.

My birth plan is to have a vaginal birth with pain relief, but if that isnâ€™t working I will have a c section rather than forceps delivery. I am choosing to have a c section under general anaesthetic rather than spinal block for similar but different reasons to you. My midwife is fine with my choice and yours should be too.

Please read the book and become an empowered birth-zilla and advocate for what you want.


[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/s?hvlocphy=9045240&hvnetw=g&hvadid=259101397804&k=positive+birth+book&gclid=CjwKCAiA8ov_BRAoEiwAOZogwZJR2agQuiQX939aygm3wF5VBZ3nap70US0JRsihtiKlgQmQjzctbRoCRSwQAvD_BwE&ref=pd_sl_24c06eh0av_e&hydadcr=21638_1763682&hvdev=m&hvqmt=e&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=kwd-302648929163&adgrpid=53111005197&hvrand=8533523911139486486]]
Cleaned_Message: right birth want section perfectly reasonable request please get copy positive birth book read right language get want birth agree probably need ask different midwife referral obstetrician talk properly decide want try vaginal birth internal voluntary decline chose cervical time someone vag need afterwards birth plan vaginal birth pain relief working section rather forceps delivery choosing section general rather spinal block similar different midwife fine choice please read book become birth advocate want positive birth book nap ref tag

Title: If anyone is still shopping for child 7+....
Message:
My son got a Crosstour action cam (cheaper Go-Pro style camera) for his birthday yesterday and it's been a massive hit. For Â£30 it comes with 2 batteries and loads of mounts, waterproof case etc. There's an app which you can use to view the videos over WiFi etc too which is fab (and saves faffing with memory card into laptop etc). Memory card is the only extra you'll need, but we've got him a few extra accessories for Christmas like a chest harness, selfie stick and such. We went out earlier with it mounted on his bike handlebars and I'm really impressed at the quality of the camera and video.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B073WWSYJK/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_bM73FbE44FJBK?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

There's other models if you're wanting any extra features, better quality video etc, but for a child this is excellent, and IMO you get much more for your money than the VTech or similar versions.
Cleaned_Message: son got action cam pro style camera birthday yesterday massive hit comes waterproof case use view memory card memory card extra need got extra like chest harness stick went mounted bike really quality camera video ref apa tag wanting extra better quality video child excellent get much money similar

Title: Why can my 9 year old not understand time?
Message:

Title: Not quite curly hair, what to do?
Message:
I have wavy hair. Fine but a lot of it. The top layer can frizz easily 
I never brush it dry. I came across curly girl a couple of years ago. I had always used the technique but not necessarily CG friendly products
My results still vary.
I would start by trying the techniques then adding product changes one at a time. My hair is quick to frizz and can quickly get overloaded with products 
At the moment I co wash then condition. I brush with conditioner in then squish it into my hair
After rinsing I put in a bit of leave in conditioner then squeeze out the water and brush again. I put gel on, I'm using naughty at the moment, and squeeze my hair to encourage curls and clumping. I usually clip the top up to dry with a claw grip for lift. I hardly touch it again. Perhaps a tiny bit of leave in or curl cream to finish off
It won't be brushed at all when dry. 
I've been thinking about this for the top bit but am still undecided as I try to avoid heat

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07X3SLZN1/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_-GY6FbQ9Z87PC?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Mousse works for a lot of fine wavies but just gives me frizz. There are UK groups for fine, wavy hair who want to use the CG method. A FB group is the best way to find CG products
Cleaned_Message: wavy hair fine lot top layer frizz easily never brush dry came across curly girl couple ago always used technique necessarily friendly still vary would start trying product one time hair quick frizz quickly get moment wash condition brush conditioner squish hair rinsing put bit leave conditioner squeeze water brush put gel naughty moment squeeze hair encourage usually clip top dry claw grip lift hardly touch perhaps tiny bit leave curl cream finish brushed dry thinking top bit still undecided try avoid heat ref apa tag mousse works lot fine frizz fine wavy hair want use method group best way find

Title: Baby wonâ€™t stay latched on
Message:
Hugs to you OP. I ended up exclusively pumping for my twins who couldnâ€™t latch properly- pretty sure it was tongue tie looking back but we had a lot more pressing issues to deal with - I was pumping anyway as they were tube fed so I kept going. 

Firstly, it sounds like youâ€™re using the wrong size flange (funnel bit) if repeatedly slipping off. Over time this will cause trauma - in the meantime if you have a stretchy bra you can spare, cut a cross in each cup as a makeshift hands free pumping bra. 

Consumer grade pumps are often a bit crap and often donâ€™t  come with different size flanges. I had an Ardo Calypso double pump which was brilliant, not expensive and comes with different sizes. Argos sell them and often have same day delivery on some things or amazon will deliver by Tuesday 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Ardo-Calypso-Double-Plus-Breastpump/dp/B00JNCTAKW/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&s=baby&keywords=ardo+calypso&sprefix=ardo+cal&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1608498828&sr=1-1]]

I think Ardo do next day delivery. 

[[https://www.ardobreastpumps.co.uk/shop/products/buy-a-breastpump/pump-up-the-volume/]]

If you canâ€™t get on with the one you have, I would get another. Good thing about Ardo Calypso is theyâ€™re a closed system so you can sell them on when youâ€™re done. 

Google the Stanford pumping technique - theres a very dated but very useful video. Combines pumping with breast compression to maximise supply.

If you want to try latching again then google the flipple technique - a way of getting a deeper latch often suggested when thereâ€™s a tie. Try some other holds - one of mine could only latch at all if lying on his right hand side, so experiment. Also have a look at rugby ball hold and laid back Feeding position, and try when he starting to get wriggly rather than crying with hunger - you can google hunger cues to show you what the earliest signs are. 

Unfortunately lots of tongue tie services are limited during COVID to those cases where the baby is not gaining weight etc. Definitely ask and be assertive  but also have a look online to see if anyone can do it privately at your home. I wish I had paid for this in hindsight but I didnâ€™t. 

I pumped every 2 hours round the clock at first which is hard going but unfortunately important to keep supply up. 

I remember only too well how desperate I felt when mine wouldnâ€™t latch - try not to panic, keep your supply up as best you can, try to get the tongue tie sorted, if you can afford it get some advice from an IBCLC lactation consultant. Just because he canâ€™t latch now doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s over - I know plenty whoâ€™ve pumped initially then managed to establish BFing, hell I even know people who have relactated after stopping completely. 

Hang in there, stay as calm as you can, stanford pumping, frequent pumping, different flanges / pump, deep latch, different holds and feed when calm before he gets too hangry. 

You can do it :)
Cleaned_Message: ended exclusively latch properly pretty sure tongue tie looking back lot pressing deal anyway tube fed kept going firstly like wrong size flange funnel bit repeatedly slipping time cause trauma stretchy bra spare cut cross cup makeshift free bra consumer grade often bit crap often come different size calypso double pump brilliant expensive comes different sizes sell often day delivery deliver calypso double plus ref baby calypso cal tag think next day delivery shop buy pump volume get one would get another good thing calypso closed system sell done technique theres useful video breast compression supply want try latching technique way getting latch often tie try one mine could latch lying right hand side experiment also look ball hold laid back feeding position try starting get wriggly rather crying hunger hunger show unfortunately lots tongue tie limited covid baby gaining weight definitely ask assertive also look see anyone privately home wish hindsight every round clock first hard going unfortunately important keep supply remember well desperate felt mine latch try panic keep supply best try get tongue tie sorted afford get advice lactation consultant latch mean know plenty initially establish hell even know people stopping completely stay calm frequent different pump deep latch different feed calm

Title: Need to scream - 5 yo
Message:

Title: DD convinced she has ADHD
Message:
Dreamscene Star Weighted Blanket for Kids Children Sleep Insomnia Therapy Anxiety Relief Autism Reversible Fluffy Teddy Fleece Throw, Blush Pink, 100 x 150cm - 3kg, DBWESTRBL01 [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B08J82C8CN/ref=cm_sw_r_em_apa_fabc_JHSH6MZD1R1FR9VY77Y5?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

This might not be big enough or heavy enough for a ten Yr old you'll have to check it out. 

Sleep deprivation nearly destroyed my marriage too, still not recovered any intimacy and will see what happens when the children are older.

In the end the two things that worked best to help my Dd were bedtime tokens system, which is a bit like this :
[[https://www.drgreene.com/bedtime-pass-program]]
But we used loads of tokens at first and gradually reduced the number, so Dd used 32 the first night and gradually reduced down to 3, if she had tokens left in the morning she got a sweet (because sod it). 

And this technique that's used for adults with 'middle insomnia', so Dd always woke at 1:30am for hours. 6:30pm bedtime because she was so tired. So she could sleep from 630-130 = 7hrs. 6am was morning, minus 7hrs she would sleep for, gave us a bedtime 11pm. The idea is for a few nights stay up until 11pm. Yes it will be horrible. Then gradually move bedtime forward in increments to a more reasonable time. We couldn't quite hack 11pm but did 9:30pm and then gradually snuck forward to 8pm. If we put her to bed much earlier she's up in the night again. She sleeps in later doing this later bedtime, until 7am usually.
Cleaned_Message: star weighted blanket sleep insomnia therapy anxiety relief autism reversible fluffy fleece throw blush pink ref apa tag might big enough heavy enough ten old check sleep deprivation nearly marriage still intimacy see older end two worked best help bedtime system bit like bedtime pass program used first gradually reduced number used first night gradually reduced left morning got sweet sod technique used middle insomnia always woke bedtime tired could sleep morning minus would sleep gave bedtime idea nights stay yes horrible gradually move bedtime forward reasonable time quite hack gradually snuck forward put bed much night later later bedtime usually

Title: If you're home schooling a reception aged child...
Message:
He sounds entirely normal OP - itâ€™s the situation that isnâ€™t! I have a reception child and a Y3 and itâ€™s very hard to keep them occupied, although my Y3 is at least able to get on with school work on his own for longer periods. 

My son in reception enjoys cosmic kids yoga, and is very keen on doing his â€˜workâ€™ on the iPad - we do try to limit this but have found Crazy Cursive (app) and Phonics Bloom (website - phonics games) to be at least vaguely educational and they hold his attention for longer periods when we need to help his brother. 

Otherwise weâ€™re doing a lot of handwriting practice. He enjoys practising his letters in sand and on wipe clean books. Also chalk on a blackboard. I remember being told that doing sensory writing helps their muscle memory. Weâ€™ve written a couple of (very short) letters to his friends and had exciting replies. He does the White Rose maths videos as well and we always end up getting out teddies/buttons on plates etc to recreate the activity so that takes up a bit of time. We get other schoolwork home but nothing great heâ€™ll concentrate on for more than max 15 minutes at a time. 

Heâ€™s just had his birthday and got some StoryOrchestra books, which have really captured his imagination. The other thing he loves doing at the moment is excavating dinosaur fossils from plaster of Paris like this
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/KandyToys-Dinosaur-Fossils-Excavation-Skeleton/dp/B00EYMDCWI/ref=mp_s_a_1_3?dchild=1&keywords=dinosaur+digging+kit+fossils&pf_rd_p=f9379ecf-b158-4af1-9ba7-e10b1fa9db88&pd_rd_wg=YNZ6h&pf_rd_r=45MQ9D2W1XKEC075FG31&pd_rd_w=duHLg&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1611210335&pd_rd_r=217a92ac-03e0-48ca-bd25-32593c68871d&sr=8-3]] - aargh, sorry, canâ€™t do clicky links. 

We made jelly the other day as well, which was a surprising hit - he loved watching it change from solid to liquid and back again [smile]

Hang on in there - itâ€™s tough, and I can only imagine how much harder if you canâ€™t get outside regularly and easily [flowers]
Cleaned_Message: entirely normal situation reception child hard keep although least able get school work longer son reception cosmic yoga keen work try limit found crazy cursive phonics bloom phonics least vaguely educational hold attention longer need help brother otherwise lot handwriting practice sand wipe clean also chalk blackboard remember told sensory writing muscle memory written couple short exciting white rose well always end getting buttons recreate activity bit time get schoolwork home nothing great concentrate time birthday got really imagination thing moment dinosaur plaster like dinosaur excavation skeleton ref dinosaur digging kit tag sorry clicky links made jelly day well surprising hit watching change solid liquid back smile tough imagine much harder get outside regularly easily

Title: Can anyone recommend me a handheld vacuum cleaner?
Message:
I have this one 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Audew-Cleaner-Handheld-Cordless-Rechargeable/dp/B07FPVQX4Q/ref=asc_df_B07FPVQX4Q/?linkCode=df0&hvnetw=g&hvpos&hvadid=310744208542&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvrand=2497567556321925005]]. 

The main reason I opted for this was was its charge Vs use time is much better than all of the other ones I looked at. 
I only tend to use it on the stairs and occasionally the sofa as I have a eufy to do the floors . 
I have never owned any others so I can't compare it to them but I am happy with it , the only problem I found is the filter gets clogged up quite easily and so reduced the suction power a bit . 
But taking it apart to empty and clan is very easy and a old tooth brush is handy for cleaning the filter properly every couple of uses . 

I dont need / use the tools on it and have not tried it with water yet . 
It comes in its own bag  so you can keep all the bits together
Cleaned_Message: one cleaner ref tag main reason charge use time much better tend use occasionally sofa never compare happy problem found filter quite easily reduced suction power bit taking apart empty clan easy old tooth brush handy cleaning filter properly every couple dont need use tried water yet comes bag keep together

Title: To feel bad about requesting ELCS?
Message:
I am glad youâ€™ve spoken further with health professionals about this.

You are not unreasonable to want an ELCS in your situation.

Last time I recommended reading The Positive Birth Book which contains lots of information on how to have a lovely CS birth, and will help you to advocate for yourself. Please read it.

Title: Weight and diabetes
Message:
If you have BED, dieting of any form (be it for health reasons or to lose weight) will make your binges worse. Look up the restrict-binge cycle.

I would advise reading this book & attempting the programme in it before starting any diets, itâ€™s what I use with
clients with BED or bulimia 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Overcoming-Binge-Eating-Second-Program/dp/1572305614?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Hiw to work a TV?
Message:
You can get HDMI cables with and without audio - I didn't realise this, and the first cable I bought cut the sound (laptop connected to large monitor).
Even if there are audio outputs, there are probably internal speakers - you can connect additional speakers for enhanced --noisy-- volume.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B08B69RGQ4/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
is the one I got a couple of months ago.
apparently the longer the cable, the more distortion, so don't get one tons longer than you need.
Cleaned_Message: get without audio first cable bought cut sound connected large monitor even audio probably internal connect additional enhanced noisy volume product tag one got couple ago apparently longer cable distortion get one longer need

Title: Stocking ideas for someone who has a dog.
Message:
It depends on how hardcore he is.

I am fairly hardcore. I would love anyone who gave me warm, waterproof, but not bulky, gloves.

Other than that:
Tick remover (you can get some quite jazzy ones)
Canine first aid items (I made my own first aid kit, but you can buy them)
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Illumiseen-LED-Dog-Collar-Rechargeable/dp/B00UAINMMK/ref=asc_df_B00UAINMMK/?hvlocphy=9045049&linkCode=df0&hvptwo&psc=1&hvnetw=g&hvadid=309842998506&hvpone&hvlocint&hvpos&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl&hvqmt&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=pla-456521627687&hvrand=7818255284535803368 These are the tops]] for light-up collars - the charge lasts ages
A dog water bottle with integrated bowl [[https://pamperedpaws.shop/products/portable-dog-water-bottle-with-expandable-silicone-flip-up-leaf-650ml?gclid=Cj0KCQiA2af-BRDzARIsAIVQUOem_7APIDy-t5N3jfQCMB_cb01huE9GA2FMCgnVqsCTiEcgtkvKiUEaAj9PEALw_wcB like this]]

Title: Come and talk to me about Nepresso machines - going to get DH one?
Message:
I donâ€™t buy anything from Nestle, and those pods are terrible for the environment, so I wouldnâ€™t recommend a Nespresso.
[[https://www.zmescience.com/science/nestle-company-pollution-children/]]

These are very good if your budget can stretch to it? De'Longhi Magnifica, Automatic Bean to Cup Coffee Machine, Espresso, Cappuccino, ESAM 4200.S, Silver [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B001EOMZ5E/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_Cgw1FbXKYTCVZ?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Come and talk to me about Nepresso machines - going to get DH one?
Message:
I am thinking about getting one and one of these as well, as I am not keen on the nespresso coffee or the impact on the environment. (Or the nanoparticles of plastic in my body). This way I get to choose my own coffee (Iâ€™m fussy af). 

There are lots of different sorts of refillable nespresso pods available, btw. You just have to get the ones that fit your machine. In the long run I think it will save you a hell of a lot of money, too.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Refillable-Stainless-Compatible-VertuoPlus-Restaurants/dp/B08HRXLN2G/ref=mp_s_a_1_5?dchild=1&keywords=refillable+stainless+nespresso+pod&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607833438&sr=8-5]]

Title: Come and talk to me about Nepresso machines - going to get DH one?
Message:
If he's not into cappuccino style then I don't think Nespresso is a good option.

My husband has a v60 filter coffee set and loves it. It's rather trendy ATM. Perfect for making coffee for 1/2 and he can add milk to it. 

See this [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B002BA2I7A/ref=cmswrcpapifabc4JD1FbZS9ADJM Hario Set]] and you could gift with a bag of decent coffee. Various similar sets available, either plastic or ceramic. Instead of a pot you can get one that goes directly over a cup too. Look up Hario brand on Amazon.

Title: Spd - make it stop

Title: Oily hair shampoo recommendation
Message:
I know this says for coloured hair but it really helps my fine lank highlighted hair. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Pureology-Shampoo-Colour-Treated-Lightweight-266ml/dp/B089165CCW?th=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

I use wella elements conditioner on the lengths and ends but the shampoo causes my patch of Seborrhoeic dermatitis to flare up after a few days. 
The other favourite and sometimes I wash with it first and double wash with the pureology is Tresemme [[https://www.boots.com/tresemme-pro-collection-collagen-fullness-shampoo-400ml-10252947]]

The pureology makes my hair feel much better though and it is really shiny. I do wash my hair every day though and still canâ€™t push to two days unless I am at deaths door or at a festival.
Cleaned_Message: know hair really fine lank hair shampoo colour lightweight tag use conditioner shampoo patch dermatitis flare days sometimes wash first double wash boots pro collection collagen fullness shampoo hair feel much better though really shiny wash hair every day though still push two days unless door festival

I buy it in massive tubs for about Â£16-  Â£20 for nearly 485g (Â£4.16 per 100g maximum if I can only find it at Â£20 per tub) If you are only buying it in 50g or 75g tubes you are probably paying between Â£8-Â£10per 100g, almost double the price per g. Title: Dad with dementia
Message:
My dad has dementia and loves it when we look through photo albums.  Many of the photos are not him at all.  I printed out photos from the internet of places he liked, and also people.  We have a section on the Queen, and a section of dog photos, with some funny ones in.  It gives us something to talk about and is a great distraction if he has got stuck on talking about one thing.  I dig out the photo album and we can laugh at some of the photos.

It's a cruel illness, and tough to see someone you love going through it.  However, you can build up good memories even at this stage in life, and enjoy doing things together.   

One thing which I bought dad, which gave him a lot of pleasure, was a dementia clock.  They are not cheap but helped him to be less confused at home.  [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Digital-Calendar-Dimmable-Impaired-Non-Abbreviated/dp/B08F1PHY4K/ref=asc_df_B08F1PHY4K/?hvlocphy=1006976&hvlocphy=1006976&linkCode=df0&hvptwo&hvptwo&psc=1&hvnetw=g&hvnetw=g&hvadid=448828521486&hvadid=448828521486&hvpone&hvpone&hvlocint&hvlocint&ref&hvpos&hvpos&hvdev=c&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl&hvdvcmdl&hvqmt&hvqmt&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=pla-937253550871&hvtargid=pla-937253550871&hvrand=6659642940371197027&hvrand=6659642940371197027&adgrpid=103516102559  like this]]  Though you have to remember to visit when the clocks go back and forward, as they don't change automatically!
Cleaned_Message: dad dementia look photo many printed also people section queen section dog funny something talk great distraction got stuck talking one thing dig photo album laugh cruel illness tough see someone love going however build good even stage life enjoy together one thing bought dad gave lot pleasure dementia clock cheap less confused home digital calendar non ref ref tag like though remember visit back forward change automatically

Title: Opinions on home birth
Message:
I'm currently pregnant with my second and considering home birth. I gave birth in the MLU last time, free of complications, but like you I can't shake the 'what if' feeling (although I'm told that you're transferred to hospital at the first sign of an issue). I hated the transfer to hospital during labour (quite late on and needed to push) and loved the pool so would like to maximise my chances of a water birth next time.

My midwife recommended this book: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Home-Birth-Matters-Pinter-Martin/dp/1780665555?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
So far, it's been a good read and is starting to ease some of my concerns re safety, practicality, etc. 

I'm now starting to worry about where I'd put a birth pool and how to keep my toddler occupied, so the MLU is starting to look attractive again, but not in the way I'd anticipated! [grin]
Cleaned_Message: currently pregnant second considering home birth gave birth last time free like shake feeling although told transferred hospital first sign issue transfer hospital labour quite late push pool would like water birth next time midwife book home birth martin tag far good read starting ease safety practicality starting worry put birth pool keep toddler starting look attractive way grin

Title: First psychiatrist appointment
Message:
I second EMDR. I had repeated childhood traumas (sexual and physical abuse, neglect) and trauma later in life. I have seen a number of psychiatrists over the years but none of them were interested in trauma, they were only interested in diagnosis and medication - neither of which helped. In fact, a diagnosis made it worse because whatever I was feeling was attributed to bipolar disorder and my traumatic history was swept under the rug.

It is only in the last couple of years, since having psychodynamic therapy, that I have begun to experience fewer depressions. I have just started EMDR after reading The Body Keeps the Score, which I would recommend to anyone who has experienced trauma. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Body-Keeps-Score-Transformation-Trauma/dp/0141978619/ref=nodl_?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] I tried to receive it on the NHS but they told me EMDR is only for â€˜traumatised peopleâ€™ which sums up their wilful ignorance of my history.

A psychiatrist may try to diagnose you with EUPD but be aware that there is a lot of controversy around this diagnosis, as it is often seen as a catch-all for people - particularly women - who grew up with trauma and thus rather invalidates their unique experiences. They may try to prescribe you antipsychotic medications like quetiapine or resperidone which can cause debilitating side effects such as weight gain or cognitive issues, and there is a lack of evidence to support their usefulness in trauma. Do read up on anything they offer very thoroughly so you can make an informed decision on whether medication is the right option for you.

There is a lot of evidence to support EMDRâ€™s effectiveness in treating trauma and there are many people who make a full recovery after treatment. You also arenâ€™t required to go into detail about the trauma, unlike other therapies that can involve talking about the trauma over and over, which is potentially retraumatising.

Good luck OP. Remember that none of this means there is something â€˜wrongâ€™ with you or that you are mentally ill. You are experiencing an understandable response to multiple traumas. The numbness you describe sounds like dissociation.
Cleaned_Message: second repeated childhood sexual physical abuse neglect trauma later life seen number none interested trauma interested diagnosis medication neither fact diagnosis made worse whatever feeling bipolar disorder traumatic history swept rug last couple since psychodynamic therapy begun experience reading body score would recommend anyone experienced trauma body score transformation trauma ref tag tried receive told people ignorance history psychiatrist may try diagnose aware lot controversy around diagnosis often seen catch people particularly grew trauma thus rather unique may try prescribe like cause side effects weight gain cognitive lack evidence support usefulness trauma read anything offer thoroughly make informed decision whether medication right option lot evidence support effectiveness treating trauma many people make full recovery treatment also detail trauma unlike involve talking trauma potentially good luck remember none something wrong mentally ill understandable response multiple numbness describe like dissociation

Title: PCOS acne. Roaccutane didnâ€™t work. Ideas?
Message:
I haven't read all the comments so apologies if I'm repeating anyone. I'm 36 and have suffered my whole adult life except for 2yrs after my first lot of accutane. Firstly, your dose doesn't sound that high. I was only on it 6months but I was on 80mg for much of that - I weigh 9stone. If the dose doesn't go high enough then I've heard that can be a reason for it not working. 
As I said though, mine came back eventually. The single biggest effect on my skin is carbs and sugar. Have you tried doing a keto diet? If not I highly recommend it. I don't do full keto - I still eat lots of veggies but avoid starchy ones like potatoes, butternut squash, sweet pot etc. So it's more low carb than no carb. I do still have dairy which I find is ok as long as carbs are low but you've gotta make sure you're having the full fat stuff. Also try and eat regularly, don't skip meals and snack on nuts to keep your blood sugar level even all day. 
In addition to this, go really gentle with your skin care regime because the more you do to the skin, the weaker the barrier. I use these products:

Evening toutine
- to remove make up: [[https://www.boots.com/garnier-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10169115?cmmmc=bmm-buk-google-ppcPLAs(GB:Whoop!)+Garnier--(GB:Whoop!)+Boots+Shopping+-+Category+-+Beauty+-+Mobile&gclid=Cj0KCQiA0-6ABhDMARIsAFVdQv-x1qBnS4NduqBv95Rp0BnHtnWOw85kcRjJzlAPeNi7QbhbgStdshsaAisYEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds https://www.boots.com/garnier-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10169115?cm]][[https://www.boots.com/garnier-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10169115?cmmmc=bmm-buk-google-ppcPLAs(GB:Whoop!)+Garnier--(GB:Whoop!)+Boots+Shopping+-+Category+-+Beauty+-+Mobile&gclid=Cj0KCQiA0-6ABhDMARIsAFVdQv-x1qBnS4NduqBv95Rp0BnHtnWOw85kcRjJzlAPeNi7QbhbgStdshsaAisYEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds mmc=bmm-buk-google-ppc]]c_[[https://www.boots.com/garnier-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10169115?cmmmc=bmm-buk-google-ppcPLAs(GB:Whoop!)+Garnier--(GB:Whoop!)+Boots+Shopping+-+Category+-+Beauty+-+Mobile&gclid=Cj0KCQiA0-6ABhDMARIsAFVdQv-x1qBnS4NduqBv95Rp0BnHtnWOw85kcRjJzlAPeNi7QbhbgStdshsaAisYEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds PLAs]]As--[[https://www.boots.com/garnier-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10169115?cmmmc=bmm-buk-google-ppcPLAs(GB:Whoop!)+Garnier--(GB:Whoop!)+Boots+Shopping+-+Category+-+Beauty+-+Mobile&gclid=Cj0KCQiA0-6ABhDMARIsAFVdQv-x1qBnS4NduqBv95Rp0BnHtnWOw85kcRjJzlAPeNi7QbhbgStdshsaAisYEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds (GB:Whoop!)+Garnier-]]-_[[https://www.boots.com/garnier-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10169115?cmmmc=bmm-buk-google-ppcPLAs(GB:Whoop!)+Garnier--(GB:Whoop!)+Boots+Shopping+-+Category+-+Beauty+-+Mobile&gclid=Cj0KCQiA0-6ABhDMARIsAFVdQv-x1qBnS4NduqBv95Rp0BnHtnWOw85kcRjJzlAPeNi7QbhbgStdshsaAisYEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds -(GB:Whoop!)+Boots+Shopping+-+Category+-+Beauty+-+Mobile&gclid=Cj0KCQiA0-6ABhDMARIsAFVdQv-x1qBnS4NduqBv95Rp0BnHtnWOw85kcRjJzlAPeNi7QbhbgStdshsaAisYEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds]]

- then I double cleanse with vanicream facial cleansing bar. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00E4MRMVK?ref=ppxpopmobapshare https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00E4MRMVK?ref=ppx]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00E4MRMVK?ref=ppxpopmobapshare pop]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00E4MRMVK?ref=ppxpopmobapshare mob]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00E4MRMVK?ref=ppxpopmobapshare ap]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00E4MRMVK?ref=ppxpopmobapshare share]]

- apply vitamin c serum (has a tiny amount of retinol so best avoid if ttc) [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07P5TMHD9?ref=ppxpopmobapshare https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07P5TMHD9?ref=ppx]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07P5TMHD9?ref=ppxpopmobapshare pop]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07P5TMHD9?ref=ppxpopmobapshare mob]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07P5TMHD9?ref=ppxpopmobapshare ap]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07P5TMHD9?ref=ppxpopmobapshare share]]

- moisturise with vanicream lite [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000TCWX68?ref=ppx_pop_mob_ap_share https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000TCWX68?ref=ppx]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000TCWX68?ref=ppx_pop_mob_ap_share pop]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000TCWX68?ref=ppx_pop_mob_ap_share mob]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000TCWX68?ref=ppx_pop_mob_ap_share ap]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000TCWX68?ref=ppx_pop_mob_ap_share share]]

- apply azelaic acid to my jawline and neck where I'm most prone to cystic acne. I get my azeliac acid from the doctor as they can prescribe a 20% version but you can also get a 10% version through the ordinary. 

In the morning I just wash and moisturise with vanicream. Perhaps use vit c serum too if skin feeling in need. 

I have very sensitive, very oily and dry skin that is prone to cystic acne along jaw and neck. This routine has improved my breakouts HUGELY. Hope it helps xx

Title: Boys long hair
Message:
DS used to use snoods [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Multifunctional-Headwear-Headbands-Bandana-Seamless/dp/B01I1EBWA8/ref=mp_s_a_1_7?dchild=1&keywords=snoods+for+men&sprefix=snood&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1611854659&sr=8-7]]
but we're a non uniform school - they became a bit popular and several other boys turned upbwith them too despite having shortwr hair. He has a ponytail on PE and art/woodwork days now though, and occassionally lets his big sister plair it, mainly to see if its ling enough to donate, which he's aiming to do when hairdressers reopen. 

For homeschooling he puts it through the gap in a Baseball Cap by preference. He's nearly 10 and has jealousy inducingly beautiful thick, shiny, straight hair.
Cleaned_Message: used use headwear seamless ref men snood tag non uniform school bit popular several turned despite hair art woodwork days though big sister mainly see ling enough donate aiming reopen gap baseball cap preference nearly jealousy beautiful thick shiny straight hair

Title: Our first month ttc our first
Message:
couldnâ€™t recommend it more.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Impatient-Womans-Guide-Getting-Pregnant/dp/1451620705/ref=nodl_?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

There are bits of it that are quite American, like what diagnostic tests to ask your ob-gyn for, and a couple of stats Iâ€™d rather not have learned (like how quick the average couple under 35 conceive!) but it totally debunks every myth youâ€™ve ever heard plus answers all questions about supplements, timing, herbs, positions, you name it. It really helped me with all my obsessive googling - answers the questions with science not opinion xx

Title: POAS Anon Christmas Party ðŸŒ²ðŸ§‘â€ðŸŽ„ Ho ho ho-ws your line progression?! Thread 3
Message:
hooray for getting to 4 weeks ðŸ™‚I called my GP receptionist and asked what the procedure is, all I had to do was self-refer to maternity services. There was a form on my local NHS maternity service site to fill in and email to the midwives. I got a reply from them the same day I sent the form in. I did it at 4+3 but I think this was quite early, there's no rush to get it sent off.

I haven't got a book yet, but was thinking I might get this one after the 12wk scan [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Day-Day-Pregnancy-Book-Experts/dp/0241312817/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=pregnancy+day+by+day+book&sprefix=Pregnancy+day&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607860981&sr=8-1]]

It looks very detailed though so it depends what you're after! I like having all the info haha, but some of the reviews say it's too much to digest.

 I'd say you maybe haven't peaked yet but you're on the way up? Are you going to test again this afternoon? That's just my guess though ðŸ™‚
Cleaned_Message: getting receptionist procedure self refer maternity form local maternity service site fill got reply day sent form think quite early rush get sent got book yet thinking might get one scan day day pregnancy book ref pregnancy day day book pregnancy day tag detailed though like say much digest say maybe peaked yet way going test afternoon guess though

Title: General aches and pains and sleep
Message:
Iâ€™m on HRT but have patches and I rarely have any hot flushes. Maybe you need to speak to the dr about your dosage?
If the springs on your mattress are going then a mattress topper isnâ€™t really going to make much difference tbh but I have a memory foam one and all our sheets/duvet covers are 100% cotton which really helps. A cotton mix tends to cause sweating. 
This has stoped a lot of muscle aches and helps with sleep. Seemingly a lot of people have magnesium deficiency and this causes aches and affects sleep. They also do a spray if you are not a body lotion type of person
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/BetterYou-Magnesium-Body-Lotion-180ml/dp/B00U6CG5QU/ref=sr_1_8?dchild=1&crid=3DMPG5IIO0VS1&keywords=better+you+magnesium&sprefix=Better+you+magn%2Caps%2C164&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609662847&sr=8-8]]

Title: Should I get an oximeter?
Message:
This is what I bought, having seen a recommendation for it. It is now Â£24.99 but I paid less for it in April:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Zacurate%C2%AE-Fingertip-Saturation-batteries-Chromatic/dp/B00SCPBKFO?ref_=ast_sto_dp&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

I bought one for my household and one for the vulnerable adult I'm in a support bubble with. I am not over-anxious but like to be prepared. (Hope for the best, prepare for the worst).

If I was to test positive for the virus, I would want to be able to check my oxygen saturation level to ensure I called for help if necessary (and to try and ensure I didn't suddenly die of 'happy hypoxia' [grin]).

I also bought new faster-measuring thermometers.

Title: I'm f**c*d aren't I
Message:
You're fucked if you *don't* stop.  You know two things:
1. The liver ^can^ recover, even from serious abuse.
2. Women in general cannot survive as much alcohol abuse as men.
Thinking you're going to die soon is an excuse to keep drinking. Shake it off.

So the best time to start is now.  On my 'last day' I actually chose not to drink. I was seriously ill and going to see the GP the next day. I knew I could drink and it wouldn't really make any difference to the outcome, but it mattered to me.  You can decide whether or not to drink today, but if you're planning to try and stop in secret, I can guarantee the decision you make today will shape how you get on.

However, my top tips would be:
1. Do not try and stop in secret. Speak to your GP.  If she/he wants blood tests doing, do them. (You also know that the bloods can come back looking relatively normal even when the damage is quite severe).
2. Do not try and stop in secret. Tell your friends you are stopping. You can call it Dry January to start off with, or [[https://www.oneyearnobeer.com/ One Year No Beer]].
3. Do not try and stop in secret. Seek help.  The right form of help is up to you.

And then beyond that - make sure you anticipate your triggers.  Be watchful for them, plan ahead. They may be unexpected. (As I've said on here many times, one of mine was getting off the bus, because I associated it with getting home from work, which meant it was wine o'clock).  Keep your hands busy - crafting, gaming, something to occupy you to stop you getting bored and restless.

For me the book that helped me was [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Beat-Booze-comprehensive-combating-problems-ebook/dp/B003Q6CX0A/ref=tmm_kin_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609670927&sr=8-1 this one]].  Get one of the ones you've been recommended today, on Kindle (you don't need an actual Kindle device to read one) and you can make a start.

It is impossible to regret giving up alcohol. You might think 'oh I missed out on x' or 'y would have been more enjoyable' but in the fundamentals, in the things that make your life, none of them are better because of alcohol.

This is hard work but it's better than dying of alcoholic liver disease.

Title: 50 Book Challenge 2021 Part One
Message:
Sorry, havenâ€™t managed to be on the thread until now because of a horrible collision between return to work and start of home schooling. Neither of them went tremendously well, and I would probably benefit from sitting down with an absorbing book to de-stress â€“ but I fear that reading time is the thing thatâ€™s going to be squeezed over the next few weeksâ€¦

*Keith* (or rather, *Viking*) Thanks for the suggestion of *Railhead* - that looks really interesting (although probably a bit old for DS at the moment, as you said). We are actually members of the Calibre audio library but had let it lapse a few months ago â€“ time to start borrowing again, I think!

Love the plums/icebox parody *Satusuki* (and good to have you back!) [grin]

*Fortuna* yikes, 45 hours is quite a commitment! I do normally listen on something between 1.1 and 1.5 speed (depending on how brisk or turgid the narration is), so hopefully it will be doable in less than that. Iâ€™m definitely tempted now â€“ it sounds like the ideal way to pass the time while cleaning the kitchen or tidying up.

Thanks also for the incredibly generous offer! We already have a Roald Dahl collection ([[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Roald-Phizz-Whizzing-Audio-Children-Collection/dp/0241431999/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 this one]]) which I bought when the Book People shut down last year (remember the chat about that?!). Iâ€™d love any CDs you have that arenâ€™t already on that collection, though â€“ thank you!

*LadybirdDaphne* thanks for a very interesting review of *Inventing Ourselves* [smile].

*Stokey* Cressida Cowell is a great suggestion, thank you â€“ I think DD (7) has already read one of the HTTYD books, and it would be great to have a series than can be enjoyed by both DCs at once. What a great thread this is for getting ideas!

*ChessieFL* DD watched a Brownies panto last month that had Anna McNuff in it â€“ I think sheâ€™s some sort of ambassador for the Brownies. Her books sounded interesting but she came across as a bit self-consciously wacky, so I wasnâ€™t sure about getting one. Itâ€™s good to have your take on it!

*Razorstorm* welcome! I read *Chasing the Dram* last year as I am also a whisky/Scotland fan. It was a very light read but I also learned quite a bit, especially about blended whisky (about which I knew nothing!).

I'm really slacking - must try and find some time to write reviews of my first couple of books as you're all putting me to shame!

Title: Hair everywhere....
Message:
She's lovely!  We got a rescue GSD in August, and I'd forgotten how much they shed.  The first few weeks were like a wild west town with all the tumbleweeds in the house.  I can recommend a few things.
A furminator will take off a lot more hair...especially if she's double coated.  That will help at the source.
A rubber sweeping brush like they use in the hairdressers is a godsend.  On wooden or tiled floors it gets every bit of hair.
Get one of these: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Remover-ACE2ACE-Reusable-Removal-Furniture/dp/B0819XVK92/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?dchild=1&psc=1&s=pet-supplies&keywords=pet+hair+roller&spLa=ZW5jcnlwdGVkUXVhbGlmaWVyPUExR1k4WFJIWklNNVNMJmVuY3J5cHRlZElkPUEwMjkwMDU4M1BTNlc5RlRRNU5WOSZlbmNyeXB0ZWRBZElkPUEwNTY3NDEwMllKOU1FRzZTNlhRMyZ3aWRnZXROYW1lPXNwX2F0ZiZhY3Rpb249Y2xpY2tSZWRpcmVjdCZkb05vdExvZ0NsaWNrPXRydWU=&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1610456938&sr=1-1-spons Hair Roller]].  It collects all the hair from your furniture and collects it in the handle.  I was amazed at how well it works.  I also use it on her bed to keep the hair level down in it.
A sticky lint roller is great for your clothes when you're leaving the house.
You can also get a product that dissolves pet hair in the wash.  Throw it in the machine when washing her bedding.
Best of luck with her

Title: Fit bit calorie deficit not losing weight
Message:
*I feel much better after starting this, mentally and even if not lighter on the scales my bloating has gone and my waist is making a tiny appearance again*

The scales are a crap measure of condition anyway because of water and muscle levels changing. It's better to go on the fit of your clothes/the comfort of your digestive system and, dare I say it, calipers?

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Tester-Calipers-Measure-Fitness-Analyzer/dp/B07TXFMJVK/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

These are brilliant, and totally lacking in modern nonsense to confuse matters.

Flip the bird to the scales - sounds like what you're doing is doing the trick, and they can't even tell!
Cleaned_Message: feel much better starting mentally even lighter scales bloating gone waist making tiny appearance scales crap measure condition anyway water muscle better fit clothes comfort digestive system dare say calipers tester calipers measure fitness analyzer tag brilliant totally modern nonsense confuse flip bird scales like trick even tell

Title: How important is teeth brushing?
Message:
Non negotiable here too for my 18 month old! What helped:
Finger Toothbrush for Toddlers,Finger Toothbrush 0 2 Years FDA Grade Soft Silicone for Clean Teeth and Gums by Noondl [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07HQVYY5W/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_.1adGbP90SK7Z?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] I brush first with these then she chews on her baby toothbrush.
- morning is right after breakfast while she is still in her highchair with bib on. Harder to wriggle away!
- evening is in the bath - she actually likes this and it means no mess.
I think having consistent timing helps. But yeah if she screams I just say â€œmummy will be quick!â€ And carry on.
Cleaned_Message: non negotiable month old finger toothbrush finger toothbrush grade soft silicone clean teeth ref tag brush first baby toothbrush morning right breakfast still bib harder wriggle away evening bath actually mess think consistent timing yeah say mummy quick carry

Title: What do I do?!
Message:
Yes to all the above for behavioural, plus if you have an open litter tray Iâ€™d switch to an enclosed one. We have this one [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Curver-Litterbox-50-3x-37-3-centimeter/dp/B00I7WL962/ref=sxin_9?cv_ct_pg=search&cv_ct_wn=osp-single-source-earns-comm&linkCode=oas&crid=ZDT13ICV2IZR&cv_ct_id=amzn1.osa.eafba5ad-ed17-4a45-be3c-981b72766894.A1F83G8C2ARO7P.en_GB&keywords=enclosed+litter+tray+cat&sprefix=Enclosed+litter+%2Caps%2C552&cv_ct_we=asin&pd_rd_i=B00I7WL962&qid=1611507093&cv_ct_cx=enclosed+litter+tray+cat&dchild=1&ascsubtag=amzn1.osa.eafba5ad-ed17-4a45-be3c-981b72766894.A1F83G8C2ARO7P.en_GB&creativeASIN=B00I7WL962&pf_rd_p=0a3a8a59-63d3-4d6d-a65e-d0be4daeb691&pd_rd_wg=2XtVT&pf_rd_r=XAVXQDB1DV43WB75R37Q&pd_rd_w=jWCUp&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&pd_rd_r=d06e1d8e-deaa-4c9c-b508-a640d7346cb0&sr=1-2-483c64d8-df78-4008-ae20-e69f683e58b1]] (although got it for Â£30 on another site) and use worldâ€™s best cat litter [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Worlds-Best-Cat-Litter-Biodegradable/dp/B009ZUGJII/ref=sr_1_4?dchild=1&s=pet-supplies&crid=1538OWXSQ9WH4&keywords=worlds%2Bbest%2Bcat%2Blitter&sprefix=Worlds%2Bbest%2Bcat%2Cpets%2C-1&th=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1611507178&sr=1-4]], which is flushable and contains the smell really well. 

For the husband, Iâ€™d have a chat about responsibility. Him not engaging with the cats is part of the problem; five mins dragging some string around will help to wear out the indoor one and make them less destructive. Itâ€™s unfair of him to ask the family to give up their pets until heâ€™s done everything he can to undesired behaviour. But itâ€™s telling the itâ€™s you on here asking for advice rather than him!

Title: Any cyclists around to help a beginner who's just bought a bike?
Message:
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00KFCYUYK/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

I have this bell on both of my bikes. I love it! It gives off a good, solid ring without being obnoxious. It's got a lovely sound and it really alerts people without you worrying about sounding rude. [wink] 

Bells are a weird one, I know. But they really, really are worth using, especially if cycling is going to be your main mode of transport and not just a recreational activity you'll be doing once in a while. You want a good bell. It's worth it. I've had these ones for about 3 years now.

Title: Any cyclists around to help a beginner who's just bought a bike?
Message:
I just get my lights off of Amazon to be honest. 

My favourite ones are these: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01EJ6LKPY/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

The beam is strong and they've been really reliable. They're easy to charge up. 

You'll go through a few bike lights, just to warn you. It's not something you need to spend loads of money on because they get stolen or they just stop working for no reason. I tend to take mine with me when I hop off my bike. And these are really easy to take off and put on.

Title: Menopause tummy weight loss
Message:
I donâ€™t think any nutritionist/dietician would advise cutting out half an avocado to save on calories, OP. 
Iâ€™m also menopausal and massively put on weight on my tummy. I lost 3 stone last year using MFP and dietdoctor.com which has lots of research-backed info on low carb eating. You can take our a free trial, but lots of info is available for free. Could you do chair based exercise? Thereâ€™s a boom called Strong Women Stay Slim, itâ€™s quite old but very sensible: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Strong-Miriam-Nelson-Wernick-Raichlen/dp/0553379453?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
